abstract: The anti-viral T cell response is drawn from the naive T cell repertoire. During influenza infection, the CD8<sup>+</sup> T cell response to an H-2D<sup>b</sup>-restricted nucleoprotein epitope (NP<sub>366</sub>) is characterized by preferential expansion of T cells bearing TRBV13<sup>+</sup> T cell receptors (TCRs) and avoidance of TRBV17<sup>+</sup> T cells, despite the latter dominating the naive precursor repertoire. We found two TRBV17<sup>+</sup> TCRs that bound H-2D<sup>b</sup>-NP<sub>366</sub> with a 180° reversed polarity compared to the canonical TCR-pMHC-I docking. The TRBV17 β-chain dominated the interaction and, whereas the complementarity determining region-3 (CDR3) loops exclusively mediated contacts with the MHC-I, peptide specificity was attributable to germline-encoded recognition. Nevertheless, the TRBV17<sup>+</sup> TCR exhibited moderate affinity toward H-2D<sup>b</sup>-NP<sub>366</sub> and was capable of signal transduction. Thus, the naive CD8<sup>+</sup> T cell pool can comprise TCRs adopting reversed pMHC-I docking modes that limit their involvement in the immune response.

bibjson.title: Reversed T Cell Receptor Docking on a Major Histocompatibility Class I Complex Limits Involvement in the Immune Response.
